questions.text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia.

The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

Duodenal atresia is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system.

It is caused due to failure of recanalization or partial recanalization of the duodenum or failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage. The anatomic variants are as follows: 

  • Type I: 
    • most common
    • mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity)
  • Type II:
    • two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present
  • Type III:
    • complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum

Clinical features:

  • Obstructive features such as
    • bilious emesis (due to duodenal obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater)
    • postprandial emesis
    • upper abdominal distension with a scaphoid lower abdomen
  • Delayed passage of meconium

Abdominal radiographs show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be considered to exclude midgut volvulus.

Treatment:

  • The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression.
  • IV fluids and parenteral nutrition are started to prevent acid-base imbalance.
  • Echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest and spine should be performed to evaluate for associated anomalies.
  • Definitive correction of the atresia is done by duodenoduodenostomy. This procedure is also preferred in cases of the concomitant or isolated annular pancreas.

questions.text: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic  for this condition

questions.solution:
The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks.

Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Turner syndrome
  • Edwards syndrome
  • Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.

Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. 

USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is diagnostic.

questions.text: An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen _________.

choices.text: During palpation over the left hypochondrium

questions.solution:
In a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the abdominal mass is best seen during test feed in the right upper quadrant. 

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, when the infant is given a test feed, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant and visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

All infants with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are evaluated with an ultrasound (investigation of choice). It confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases.

Management: Rehydration and metabolic correction prior to definitive surgery - Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following statements is true regarding her condition?
  1. Visible peristalsis from left to right is seen.
  2. The vomitus is generally bilious.
  3. Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis can be associated.
  4. Cervix sign and antral nipple sign are seen in contrast studies.
  5. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.
questions.solution:
Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age.

When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography:

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

The given ultrasound image shows thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign.

Treatment:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.text: Which part of the GIT is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult?
questions.solution:
Tonometry studies have shown that of all the parts of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), the stomach is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult and is also the slowest to recover.

This may explain the high incidence of stress ulceration in the stomach.

The Griffiths point (or Griffiths critical point) refers to the site of watershed anastomosis between the ascending left colic artery and the marginal artery of Drummond occurring in the region of the splenic flexure. Most anatomy texts describe its location as two-thirds along the transverse colon.

The Sudeck point (or Sudeck critical point) refers to a specific location in the arterial supply of the rectosigmoid junction, namely the origin of the last sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of upper GI bleeding is peptic ulcer.

The causes of upper GI bleed in decreasing order of frequency: 

  • Ulcers
    • Esophageal (6%)
    • Gastric (21%)
    • Duodenal (33%)
  • Erosions
  • Mallory–Weiss tear
  • Esophageal varices
  • Tumour
  • Vascular lesions

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction. 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

Melena is the passage of black, tarry stools. It is seen in upper GI bleeding. Hematochezia is the passage of fresh blood with stools. It is seen in lower GI bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of vomiting, presents with hematemesis. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found in the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mallory Weiss tear. It is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction.

It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Mallory Weiss tear

  1. Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting.
  2. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy.
  3. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails.
  4. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail.

Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Here all layers are involved. Clinical features include Mackler's triad

  • Retching
  • Chest pain
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated venules in the submucosa of the antrum.

On endoscopy: Watermelon stomach.

Management of GAVE

  • Endoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC)
  • If persistent - antrectomy.

Dieulafoy lesion is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along the lesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

Management of Dieulafoy lesion: 

  • Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy
  • Angiographic embolization.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of increasing heartburn and dyspepsia for the past several months. He was prescribed PPIs for one month but he has no relief. You perform a urea breath test which is found to be positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the positive urea breath test are suggestive of a Helicobacter pylori infection which is most commonly associated with Type B gastritis.

Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronic pan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type A gastritis. 

Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4 ‘A’s:

  • Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cells
  • Atrophy of parietal cell mass
  • Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
  • Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor is also produced by parietal cells)

questions.text: Which of the following causes gastritis in patients with AIDS?
questions.solution:
Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) gastritis is secondary to infection with cryptosporidiosis.

Other specific types of gastritis:

  • Eosinophilic gastritis appears to have an allergic basis and is treated with steroids and cromoglycate.
  • Granulomatous gastritis is seen rarely in Crohn’s disease and also may be associated with tuberculosis.
  • Phlegmonous gastritis is a rare bacterial infection of the stomach, found in patients with severe intercurrent illnesses.

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastric ulcer is the lesser curvature near incisura.

Approximately 60% of ulcers are in this location and are classified as type I gastric ulcers.

These ulcers are generally not associated with excessive acid secretion and may occur with low to normal acid output.

questions.text: Which type of gastric ulcer has increased gastric acid levels?
questions.solution:
Gastric ulcers of Types II (gastric body with duodenal ulcer) and III (prepyloric) are associated with increased gastric acid levels.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slide is given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.

choices.text: Causes the most common type of gastritis
Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen

questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected with Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia.

The ammonia released by H. pylori acts on the antral G-cells and releases gastrin. This is responsible for hypergastrinemia in these patients resulting in type B gastritis (the most common type of gastritis).

Urea breath test and antibodies to H. pylori help us with diagnosis. The gold standard investigation for H. pylori is a tissue biopsy.

H. pylori is classified by the WHO as a class I carcinogen because of the production of certain cytotoxins, notably the Cag A and Vac A, which are implicated in gastritis, peptic ulceration, and cancer.

Helicobacter pylori was first described by Bircher. Warren and Marshall ingested the organism to confirm that Koch’s postulates could be fulfilled with respect to gastritis.

questions.text: What is the most common complication that you expect in patients suffering from peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of peptic ulcer disease is bleeding, followed by perforation and obstruction. 

The most common site for perforation of peptic ulcers is the first part of the duodenum.

Complications of peptic ulcers are

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage. 

Stigmata of Recent Hemorrhage

Forrest Classification

Active Spurting

I A

Active Oozing

I B

Non-bleeding vessel

II A

Adherent Clot

II B

Flat Pigmented Spot

II C

Clean Based Ulcer

III

Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding.

Option B: The Glasgow–Blatchford bleeding score (GBS) is a screening tool to assess the likelihood that a patient with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient’s blood urea level, hemoglobin level, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Option C: Rockall score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with an upper GI bleed.

Option D: The Bismuth–Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the tumor location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly involved vessel in patients with bleeding peptic ulcers on the posterior wall?
questions.solution: The most common vessel responsible for bleeding in peptic ulcer disease is the gastroduodenal artery. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was admitted to the burns ward with an involvement of 45% of the body surface area. She is at an increased risk of developing ulcers in which of the following parts of the stomach?
questions.solution:
A patient with burn is at risk of developing Curling’s ulcers (stress ulcers). Stress ulcers in the stomach are located most commonly in the fundus.

Stress gastritis occurs after a physical trauma, shock, sepsis, hemorrhage, or respiratory failure. It is characterized by multiple superficial (non-ulcerating) erosions that begin in the proximal or acid-secreting portion of the stomach and progress distally. They are almost always seen in the fundus of the stomach and usually develop within 1 to 2 days after a traumatic event.

The stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypotension and reduced blood flow leading to mucosal injury.

On microscopic examination, they appear as wedge-shaped mucosal hemorrhages, with coagulation necrosis of the superficial mucosal cells. Stress ulcers present as painless upper GI bleeds.

Note: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, his vitals are stable and there is abdominal rigidity and tenderness. The erect X-ray of the abdomen is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum and the patient is posted for emergency laparotomy. It reveals the presence of a perforated type I gastric ulcer. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Perform distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis
Closure of the perforation with Graham's patch repair

questions.solution:
In stable patients without operative risks, Perforated type I gastric ulcers are best managed by distal gastrectomy with Billroth I anastomosis (with or without vagotomy).       

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable or unfit for surgery, simple patch repair with biopsy preferred.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      

Type of Gastric Ulcer Management
Type I  Distal gastrectomy 
 Type II and III Distal gastrectomy + Vagotomy
 Type IV

 

 Csendes procedure

 or

 Pauchet procedure

 or

 Kelling - Madlener procedure

questions.solution:
The Kelling-Madlener procedure is done for type lV Gastric ulcers.

Surgical management of type lV gastric ulcer

  • Kelling-Madlener procedure - involves antrectomy and excision of gastric ulcer.
  • Pauchet’s procedure - involves distal gastrectomy with a selective sleeve-like extension to the lesser curvature to remove the ulcer.
  • Csendes Procedure- subtotal gastrectomy with sleeve-like extension to the lesser curvature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man on SSRI presented with hematemesis and abdominal pain. An endoscopy was performed immediately which showed an actively bleeding ulcer of size 2cm in the posterior wall of the duodenum. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step to manage the above scenario is endoscopic electrocoagulation.

Management of bleeding peptic ulcer

For actively bleeding ulcers or non-bleeding visible vessels,

  • Endoscopic therapy with a combination of epinephrine injection and electrocoagulation is done. Surgery is done only when 2 attempts of endoscopic therapy fail.
  • Surgical management includes duodenostomy and under-running of the vessel. Duodenal ulcers also show a good response to acid-reducing surgery or vagotomy.

 Medical management includes PPIs and H.pylori eradication therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred approach for treating a patient who has a duodenal ulcer with a perforation of 2.5cm?

choices.text: Primary closure and buttress with well-vascularised omentum

questions.solution:
The preferred treatment of perforations between 1–3 cm in size is a Graham patch repair.

Treatment of perforated duodenal ulcer:

  • <1 cm: Primary closure + buttress with well-vascularised omentum
  • 1–3 cm: Graham patch repair
  • >3 cm: Closure of defect using omentum or jejunal serosa + pyloric exclusion + gastrojejunostomy

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the type of vagotomy shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The picture depicts Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV). Post-procedure acid reduction is minimum in HSV.

It involves resection of crowfoot branches, 6cm from the gastroesophageal junction but stopped 7cm from the pylorus. The nerve of Latarjet from the anterior and posterior vagal trunk supplies the acid pepsin areas of the stomach. It is spared in HSV. Usually, the motor branch to the pylorus is also preserved.

There are 3 types of vagotomy

  1. Highly selective vagotomy
  2. Truncal vagotomy + gastrojejunostomy 
  3. Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy.

Highly selective vagotomy

  • Acid reduction is minimum.
  • Highest ulcer recurrence rate.
  • Minimum postoperative complications.

Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy

  • Acid reduction is maximum.
  • Least ulcer recurrence rate.
  • Maximum postoperative complications.

Note: Vagal nerves are motor to the stomach and denervation of the antro-pyloro-duodenal segment results in gastric stasis after truncal vagotomy. Hence, a drainage procedure, most commonly Heineke–Mikulicz pyloroplasty or gastrojejunostomy is done along with vagotomy.

The criminal nerve of Grassi is a branch of the posterior vagal trunk that arises at the gastroesophageal junction and supplies the fundus of the stomach. It is called a criminal nerve because it is often missed during vagotomy procedures and can result in recurrent peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. Guarding is present on per abdomen examination. HR is 110bpm and BP is 88/60mmHg. Erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with, for managing this case?
  1. USG abdomen
  2. IV fluids
  3. Exploratory laparotomy
  4. Elective surgery
  5. Conservative management
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and erect X-ray abdomen showing gas under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of gastrointestinal perforation. It is managed by initial resuscitation with IV fluids followed by exploratory laparotomy. It is a surgical emergency.

Management includes:

  • Adequate preoperative resuscitation with intravenous fluids followed by correction of electrolyte imbalance, instituting broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and
  • Early surgical intervention/laparotomy to address the cause for pneumoperitoneum and stop further contamination of the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. Examination revealed tenderness over the right iliac fossa. USG showed gas around the right kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pneumoretroperitoneum caused by a perforated duodenal ulcer.

Posterior duodenal ulcer perforates into the retroperitoneum, and the contents leak through the right paracolic gutter into the right iliac fossa, mimicking appendicitis. This is called Valentino syndrome.

On USG, gas can be seen around the right kidney known as the renal veil sign.

questions.text: A 30-year-old actress who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity, presents with complaints of sweating, palpitations, epigastric fullness, and loose stools which start immediately after meals. Which of the following would you not associate with her condition?

choices.text: It is precipitated by carbohydrate rich food.
It is more common after partial gastrectomy with the Billroth II reconstruction.
It is relieved by lying down.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia​ does not occur in early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raised insulin levels.

Dumping syndrome is a complication occurring post gastrectomy. It can be early or late.

Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This fluid shift induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects such as:

  • Epigastric fullness
  • Sweating
  • Lightheadedness
  • Tachycardia
  • Diarrhea

Symptoms are aggravated by having more food and relieved by lying down.

Late dumping syndrome is due to an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This hypoglycemia causes a catecholamine surge, which results in predominantly cardiovascular effects such as:

  • Diaphoresis
  • Tremulousness
  • Light-headedness
  • Tachycardia
  • Confusion

The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food.

The principal treatment for both types of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. Meals based on fat and protein are known to work the best. Octreotide before meals is useful.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching with minimal vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. A chest X-ray showed diffuse distension of bowel loops and a left-sided diaphragmatic defect. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Organoaxial type is associated with a diaphragmatic defect
Surgery is performed through a transabdominal approach

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Organoaxial gastric volvulus is more common (66%) than mesenteroaxial volvulus (33%). 

Organoaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus: Torsion occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

The Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with production of little vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Management involves reduction and uncoiling of the stomach through a transabdominal approach.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease.

Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss refractory to cetuximab.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection
